section â€¹Convergence of Branchesâ€º

text â€¹The process transforms assertions of form \<^term>â€¹(If P A B)â€º into the canonical form (â€¹âˆƒâˆ§â€º-MTF).
  Assertions \<^term>â€¹(If P A B)â€º can be yielded from branch statements.
  Data refinements in Ï†-BI are represented syntactically and the automation upon them is
  syntax-driven. We can call â€¹âˆƒâˆ§â€º-MTF canonical because on the form the refinements are expressed
  explicitly in a direct syntax. By converting \<^term>â€¹(If P A B)â€º into the canonical form, we actually
  resolve the join of the refinements from two branches, i.e., we find out for each object what is
  its abstraction after the branch join, according to its abstractions in the two branches.

  The two branches may have identical Ï†-types but may disordered. The process sorts the Ï†-types.
  One certain object may be specified by two different refinements. The process
  recognizes which two Ï†-types in the two branches are specifying the object, and applies ToA
  to transform one to another.
  To recognize this, we rely on syntactic rule binding on each specific Ï†-type to give an identifier
  of the object. An identifier can be a term of any logic type. If the syntactic rule is not given
  for a Ï†-type, we only support the case when the two branches have identical Ï†-types.

  In the implementation, we always transform Ï†-types in the right-side branch to those in the left side,
  i.e., from â€¹Bâ€º to â€¹Aâ€º for \<^term>â€¹(If P A B)â€º.
â€º

consts br_join :: â€¹actionâ€º

definition Identifier_of :: â€¹('c,'a) Ï† â‡’ 'id â‡’ ('c2,'a2) Ï† â‡’ boolâ€º
  where â€¹Identifier_of T identifier pattern â‰¡ Trueâ€º
  â€• â€¹The â€¹patternâ€º matches any Ï†-type specifying the objects of identifier â€¹idâ€º.
      By partially transforming a BI assertion to the â€¹patternâ€º, we can find from the BI assertion
      a Ï†-type specifying the object â€¹idâ€ºâ€º

Ï†property_deriver Identifier_of 555 for (â€¹Identifier_of _ _ _â€º)
  = â€¹Phi_Type_Derivers.meta_Synt_Deriver
      ("Identifier_of", @{lemma' â€¹Identifier_of T identifier patternâ€º by (simp add: Identifier_of_def)},
       SOME @{reasoner_group %cutting})â€º
